good evening people i want to uh continue our discussion of the end of

more independent more politically and even morally
liberated movies that appear after the Hollywood dispensation has subsided uh

a very remarkable decade but I think they might also share my sense that the films had given up more than they
realized certainly more than they were conscious of that the shift in the in the in the what we might call the media
ecology of the society which enabled this level of freedom for movies also carried with it
a tremendous cost and remember how decisive the numbers are I've mentioned them a few times in this course at the
height of the studio era twothirds of the country is going to the movies every week it's an habitual experience for
most Americans both adults and children really by the time this system comes to
an end after in this uh by the time the movies have been as I've suggested
several times in the course supplanted by television as the new central storytelling system of the society by
the time that occurs at the end of the 60s most Americans are going to the movies only once a once a year and it's
only particular subcultures teenagers for example who make a regular habit of going to the
movies and a good deal of the triviality and
superficiality of movies of the of many of the box office successes of the 80s

consequences for the uh nature of the the movie's sense of its connection to

of his defining qualities as a director signature features of his work the first

luckily for Alman he emerges in a time when the tyranny of the studios and also
the creative input of the studios has long has has has disappeared has gone
away um and and and in that sense in that sense he represents a new kind of

um a second so so one of his defining qualities is a kind of moral skepticism
a kind of sympathy we might call it which is connected to his what we might
call his sympathy for the marginal over and over again in Altman's films we focus on either marginal figures in
a who are part of a who are reluctantly or inadequately part of a larger
community uh or we focus on a community that itself is so dubious as a community
so damaged as a community so infeebled and unlike the traditional communities
that it's as if the community he treats itself the societies or groupings that

and uh there's a kind of of countercultural ambiencece a kind of
countercultural skepticism and sympathy for the margins in nearly all of Robert

said to have at least two dimensions one is a what we might call an aesthetic dimension in which he is skeptical about

both qualities show up in his films in all kinds of remarkable ways uh uh I've

non of the of of the of the weird and the strange in Altman that you can feel
in his in in in in his films in his casting and in his subject matter another aspect of another thing
that I would identify as a kind of defining quality for Robert Alman is the
u relation in his films especially his mature films between plot and character
there's a tendency in it's an aspect of his skepticism he doesn't like structures that control him and from one
angle if you think about storytelling or narrative uh the uh plot is a kind of
controlling feature it it it it it especially if you allow the plot to take
to take take the foreground of the to to assume a position in the foreground of the text the the plot can become a kind
of iron hand controlling the choices the director make makes controlling what can

totally ploted films uh tend to have stereotyped or flat characters in them
but Alman even when he embraces certain genre principles that require what looks
like a conventional linear plot is often tries to subvert the linearity of his
plot there's a kind of digressive or or or
dissenting uh nonlinear tendency in Altman's work you can sense it in McCabe
and Mrs miller although it doesn't emerge really totally fully until later in his career especially a little bit
later in his career the fullest embodiment of this non-plot principle of this preference for character over plot
I think is probably the film Nashville 1975 uh in which you see an in which Alman

centers of interest they seem to have no connection to each other and you sit there in the film when the film first

of the plot do come together toward the end of the film but the truth is that Alman is at least as interested in
digression as he is as he is in linear in linear progression and there is a
sense in which his films like to pause and savor what's going on around them and if you as you're watching McCabe and

principles of digression and one of the reasons that he does apart from the fact that he wants to savor the experience of

his preoccupation then is with trying to create a situation in which character
